segments.text: One, two, three, four.
One, two, three, four.
Five, six, seven, eight.
Five, six, seven, eight.
This is November 22nd.
My calendar's around every reason I'm glancing at it.
37 years ago at this moment, we were hearing the news of the assassination of President Kennedy.
I have the honor and joy of chatting with former Dean of Medicine Robert Stone,

Bob, to begin with, would you introduce yourself to anyone who might listen or read the transcript of this, describe where you grew up, what mom and dad did, where did you go to high school and college, experience before coming to A&M?
I was born in Manhattan.
on what had been the site of Peter Stuyvesant's farm but was no longer Peter Stuyvesant's farm.
Early on we moved to Winston-Salem and then subsequently returned during the Depression to Brooklyn and I went to grade school, finished grade school in Brooklyn
went to a boys high school in Brooklyn.
It was called Boys High School, had been and was still, I think, a distinguished institution that taught Latin and Greek.
It was an ethnically very mixed neighborhood, but also in transition.
It's now part of Bedford-Stuyvesant, which is the Brooklyn equivalent of Harlem.
There's a difference.

I went from there to Brooklyn College and I think Brooklyn College was a distinguished school at that time too I was an extremely poor student on probation alternate years academic probation and in 1942 I joined the

United States Navy was in the Navy for four years and then and knew for some years that I wanted to go to medical school I was accepted at the what was then called Long Island College of Medicine during the time that I was there it was absorbed by the
State University of New York and became SUNY downstate.
Received my degree there and went up to Columbia Presbyterian for two years of pathology and then as part of the original faculty at UCLA in medicine as that school was being developed.
What year was that?
I finished my formal pathology training at UCLA.
UCLA had, oh, I was due for a sabbatical and proposed to go to Rockefeller Foundation, which I did, and then to go on from there for the second six months to the Netherlands.
electron microscopy of viruses.
But UCLA had developed a bilateral arrangement with Yale University to staff the Atomic Bomb Casualty Commission office in Hiroshima and Nagasaki.
And I was given the opportunity then to extend my sabbatical for another six months to make it one year.
So, with a baby that had just been born, was a week old, my spouse and I went to Hiroshima and I worked there for a year on the late effects of atomic radiation and then returned to UCLA in 1963.
I was invited to become a member of the founding faculty at the University of New Mexico Medical School in Albuquerque.
I was chairman of the department, subsequently became dean and vice president, and then took another sabbatical, this time as a visiting professor of management at the Sloan School, MIT.
While I was there,
I was, as far as I was concerned, unexpectedly invited to go and head the NIH, which I did for two years.
I had substantial, what shall I say, personality differences with the hierarchy and HEW, HEW it was at that time, and was invited to leave.

So I left there and went to the University of Oregon Health Sciences Center in Portland as dean and vice president, stayed for about two and a half, maybe three years, and then had an opportunity to come to Texas A&M.
How did A&M and you first communicate?
Who spotted you?
I think Dr. Prescott telephoned me.
I don't know where he got my name,
I was interested, we had a little dinner about two months ago honoring Sam Black and Jeanette Farris was there.
We got into a lot of reminiscing about the initiation of the medical program because our guest speaker was Jim Schofield.
Jim had been the secretary for the liaison committee on medical education at the time that it was proposed to start the medical school here in conjunction with Baylor College of Medicine.
And so we prodded Jim to reminisce.
There was a dean, I don't know his name,
who was at Baylor, who was sort of designated as the A&MD, and you perhaps remember him.
And then Knight was appointed.
In the course of the conversation, Jeanette told me that my name had been proposed prior to Dr. Knight's, but the conclusion here, and maybe you were a part of it, I don't know.
was that I could not be moved from Oregon.
So they had invited Knight to come.
I never inquired into the circumstances that led to Dr. Knight's retirement or whatever.
But in any case, at that time, there was a real question
in the minds of the regents, Joe Reynolds and others, as to whether the medical school should continue at all.
And Reynolds and Mac Prescott, I guess, went up to see Jim Schofield and discussed how and should they close the school.
And it was apparently in that conversation that my name was proposed, seemingly already somewhat familiar to them.
And so Mac called me.
Do you remember your reaction to the call?
Was it positive, negative?
Well, I had been on the liaison, a member of the liaison committee on medical education.
At the time, the proposal came before that body or the establishment of the medical school at Texas A&M.
I think it's fair to say that all of us were very skeptical.
It sounded like a rather bizarre undertaking as it was proposed.

And so I would say this, to circle back slightly, that from the perspective of Albuquerque, I had long looked at Texas as an extremely wealthy state, one which supported medical education enthusiastically and handsomely.
And so I was tantalized by the possibility that the state would do equally well at Texas A&M as it had done at the University of Texas.

All right, while we're at this point chronologically, before we could get any kind of preliminary certification approval, back when the plan with Calhoun and Williams was a three-way working relationship
including Baylor.
Yes.
We never could get any tentative approval of that.
You bet.
Then I one day found some reference that one of the key people at the national level had worked at Baylor and he and Dr. DeBakey had not gotten along.
Who was that?
That was Jim Schofield.
All right.
And so I called that to Calhoun's attention and he said, okay, we'll try.
And so the Baylor

official link was eliminated and very quickly our yes yes yes it was not as far as I can tell and as I say I did have I do have some insight into this from a different perspective 180 degrees different that Schofield was not being vindictive vis-a-vis Baylor that it was far more complicated academically complicated in the eyes of the review committee yes
Yes, indeed.
When Prescott called you, how soon before y'all followed up after his first call?
I don't remember precisely, but it might have been as much as a week.
Did somebody visit?
Did you come down here?
Oh, I came down, yes.
Yes, I came down.
felt, and I guess that was true, proven to be true, that we hit it off very well, very quickly.
We went to the Texan for supper.
That was the elite, I guess, the most distinguished place in town to go and eat, and so we went there.
And who was your host during most of the visit, Prescott?
I think so.
I don't remember clearly.
And what was your impression of what was here?
Well, I had been on the ground floor in the establishment of UCLA and of the University of New Mexico.
I had become part of a loosely constituted group
which were of individuals, administrative individuals, involved with the establishment of new medical schools.
It was rather a closed group.
And I had a lot of enjoyment about that was a time when, I'm going back a little bit, a time when there was a whole surge of new medical schools being established.
In fact, Texas A&M was at the tail end of that rather than the height of that.

But the notion of establishing a new medical school and having, I took it that it was establishing a new medical school to come here, although some being on hand already would not have viewed it that way and did not.
But I saw it as an opportunity to, without being, I guess, pretentious or overbearing, of shaping what a medical school might be.
and I knew something of the clinical arrangements that could be established.

I had been through some severe internecine battles both at UCLA and at New Mexico and knew what the impact was of coming in and establishing a new medical school in the face of a practicing profession no matter how much

at the opening they said they were interested they invited the medical school enthusiastic uh... in those two instances and elsewhere around the country there invariably was bloodshed and so i saw an opportunity to develop the affiliation with scott and white along a totally new direction the only thing at least is somewhat comparable to it was mayo which was different because mayo medical school is a wholly owned subsidiary

And I might say parenthetically that the expectation of a few of the physicians already on hand here was not at all that we'd have that arrangement, but rather that they would establish themselves as professors in the new medical school, be distinguished, and benefit financially from it.
And so they didn't view with enthusiasm the notion of this new arrangement either.
But I was intrigued at the idea of,
of a new medical school being able to do something different and becoming the dean of three medical schools.
Did you have any key discussions with anyone other than Vice President Prescott?
Oh I did of course.
I knew the medical education establishment very well.
I guess it's not unfair to say I was part of it.
So yes, I did consult with some people and get their notions about what the prospects were here and how colleagues on the LCME would react to some proposals which were rather different from usual.
What advice did they give you?
Just stay in Oregon.
Stay in Oregon?

go so far as to indicate they didn't think this program would ever survive yes oh they did yes yes and there are some who still believe that um all right then here on the campus with whom did you have serious discussions other than dr prescott jarvis miller and uh williams and those were the only people in general what what did they oh they were 100 supportive
100% enthusiastic.
I would say that those three individuals, I can't imagine three individuals who would have been more supportive.
Oh, and there's another one that should be mentioned, and that is Walter Brindley.
I did have a couple of good sessions at Scott and White and discussed with them what would happen if
if they became part of a medical school, particularly a state medical school.
And with some trepidation, I can recall asking them, a group around the table, the board, the Scott and White board, I said, I'm not interested in being provocative.
But as a state medical school, we will have to take students of all ethnic backgrounds.
We have got to do it.

there were all white faces around the table and all males as you can imagine and I said what happens when we have black medical students or I really wasn't conscious of the Hispanic issue at that time but I said black and I was reassured by those southern gentlemen that they would accept them
that they would fit in, they would be treated as members of the student body, and there would be no problem.
There never was, to my knowledge.
At least none ever came to my attention.
Not a bit.
It was some years, I think, before we had our first black student, but there was no problem.
But I was afraid that I would get read out.
Now, this conversation, what year was this?
Oh, that must have been 1977.
I'm not certain, but I think so.
When did you arrive?
I think 77.
Might have been the tail end of 76.
Did we yet have medical, were we already, did we already have medical students?
24 first-year students.
They were already enrolled.
They had

they had by then I guess really finished the first year and that's what the problem was in the minds of Reynolds the other regents and Prescott as to what to do with those students if they closed the school would there be a place for them elsewhere in the country now was there as far as you were aware when you arrived was there any question about funding no
And that probably was, to some extent, my fault.
That is, I didn't pursue that.
I didn't hammer on it.
I was simply told that there would be resources available to develop a medical school.
And I took that at face value.
Did Williams, Miller, Prescott, and others make any commitments about facilities funding and staffing?
No, no.
And you didn't lay down any conditions?
No, no.
There was already a notion and maybe a commitment on the part of the regents, I'm not certain about this, to build a basic science building and that there would be plenty of land available.
I did not believe and still do not believe that we needed or wanted a university hospital and that, although I must say that the men that I dealt with were men of
enormous goodwill.
I don't think they understood what it would mean to have a university hospital.
I've been there in Missouri.
I know what that means, or some of what that means, and I know how many headaches they have missed as a result of it.
Yes.
Let's see, and the only money question I'm going to ask, what was your beginning salary?
Do you remember?
I don't remember.
It was, in my mind at that time, generous.
But it was not sufficient to attract me here.
Did it compare with what you were making in Oregon?
I know it did because I know that the folks here made inquiry at Oregon as to what my salary was.
But I simply do not remember.
I'm not dissembling.
I simply don't remember what it was.
Describe the move of you and your

wife and any family you had with you at that time describe your move here how did that go physical relocation well there's no problem about Mary and me Lael would have been Lael is my daughter would have been at that time if we're talking about 1977 she would have been 17 years old
And there was a question of where she would or should go to school.
So she had been at the National Cathedral School when we were in Washington.
She then, I guess, went to Concord Academy, and she was applying to medical school.
Oh, I will tell you a little story about that.
And she was applying to college.
And partly because we were already on the West Coast, she had applied to Stanford and been admitted to several schools, but admitted to Stanford.
And so I guess there was no big problem about her moving.
It was just about the time that she started.
I'd need to check the dates, but I think she was just about to enter Stanford.
Shortly after we got here and got settled and were so pleased with our only child matriculating at Stanford, we were invited to some sort of reception where people ask, you know, your family.
We had one daughter.
Where is she?
She's at Stanford.
Oh, she'll be transferring here, won't she?
Maybe you better not put that in the record.
No, no, I think that's a good one.
There must have been some other experiences you had about comparing life on the West Coast and D.C. with here.
How easy was it to become a Texan?
Well, you see, it wasn't all that different.
I had been a Southerner.
I had a good part of my life grown up, or a good part of an impressionable
I'd grown up in Winston-Salem.
I even went occasionally to Baptist Sunday School.
And then I had lived in New Mexico.
And I wasn't the stereotypical Easterner, New Yorker, maybe even worse, a Brooklynite, to put it right at the bottom.
So I didn't feel that there was much that I needed to adapt very much.
Jim Schofield reminded me when we had this little dinner the other time that I had asked him for advice before coming out here.
Jim boasts about being a fourth or fifth generation Texan and coming.
You use the term hard shell Baptist.
That's where he comes from.
He talks about it as his background, but he said,
Well, what I told you was don't talk so fast.
That was my total sociological adjustment.
When you arrived, describe where the students and the faculty and the medical school facilities were located.
Well, sure.

they were in several buildings the students were in several buildings and most notably in Teague I need to go back a little bit again historically when I went to UCLA our first offices were in Quonset huts literally Quonset huts and in the religious conferences building which was taken out in order to give us some room to start the medical school
We grew into a rather massive structure.
But in 1963, when I went to Albuquerque, we started out in a converted, literally, seven-up bottling plant with a broken pane of windows in the front and a mortuary, which they bought for us.
Fortunately, they were adjacent to the campus.
It became part of the campus.
So it wasn't a shock to me to move into those kind of quarters.

Additionally, because I had been doing so much visiting as part of accreditation of medical schools around the country, I was very familiar with what were called surge facilities, where the program at Davis was one of the most beautiful I've ever seen.
Davis, of course, an agricultural school by heritage,

they started in the university stable and they had taken the stables which were made of fine old redwood and made the most beautiful quarters you can imagine well that was that was the ultimate way to go with the surge facilities so it didn't bother me a bit that we were in temporary facilities here I knew that we would be getting something in addition and who were the key faculty members that were here

yeah virtually all of the well all of the what's so-called preclinical department heads had been appointed the only one who was new coming just before I came but whom I had an opportunity to sign off on was George Cho but Garrett Iler was here

Wagner was here on anatomy Sam Black I hope you'll talk with Sam if you haven't done so already all right and let's see oh Joyce Davis with whom you ought to talk to Phil was on the faculty an internist and Phil was one of those doctors this I think needs to be filtered filter Phil was one of those people who anticipated being

professor of medicine and having a practice in the medical school and when he saw the way things were going he went into town and set up his practice didn't bother Joyce a bit yes and that's one place that I feel very strongly negative and that was Elvin Smith
I have subsequently come to believe that this, I guess you better turn off, really.
To go to this issue of joining up with Scott and White, it wasn't clear what we would do in the way of clinical facilities.
There was the possibility that somehow we would work at the St. Joseph Hospital.
I went to Austin and had some interviews there at Breckenridge.

talked with the faculty with the physicians on the staff there to look at the possibility that the last two years of the medical school would be in Austin rather than in Scott and White and subsequently it was I think I don't think it's overstating it to say it was my decision that we would go with Scott and White and we'd establish the relationship there and it would bring along the VA hospital
for somewhat political reasons, but also substantive reasons.
And there was, Alvin did not support that.
And it has been, it has seemed to be on his agenda from that time on to separate the college from Scott and White.
When did you first begin to interact with Dr. Brindley?
Oh, within the first week or month or something like that.
I mean, I probably met them when I first came here before I had taken the job.
Describe Dr. Brindley, first of all, by personality.
Well, he was a courtly southern gentleman.
He didn't have a white beard, but he could have been Colonel Saunders or something.
There was no question about that.
And his official, he was president of?
He was president of the Scott and White Clinic Board.
I think they called, yes, president.
And so he was, in fact, the CEO.
Oh, yes, indeed, indeed, indeed.
And what was his basic attitude about the A&M relationship?
Oh, he was enthusiastic.
I don't think there's any question.
I think he did not know how to mentally compute
The, I'm going to call them power relationships, just to be simple and fast.
But the authority relationships, the responsibility relationships as between the university and Scott and White.
And that was a major problem for both the faculty here and the faculty in Temple, to understand how they could work together.

and how they would be how they might be taking orders from somebody else that is still I think it's greatly diminished but that also always was an underlying question of well what would be the dean's authority would the dean decide whether or not Scott and White could hire such and such a physician
And I think that that was the best part of the relationship that I had with Scott and White.
